answers.explanation:
The OCT macula of the right eye demonstrated a hypo-reflective dome-shaped space separating the neurosensory retinal layers from the retinal pigment epithelium (RPE). This is characteristic of neurosensory retinal detachment secondary to the accumulation of subretinal fluid (red arrow). There is no hyper-reflective layer on the inner limiting membrane to suggest an epi-retinal membrane. There is no discontinuation of RPE layer or increased hyperreflectivity that would suggest RPE atrophy.

![](/content/media/retina_72_2.webp)

questions.title: Question 1
questions.text: What abnormality is visualized in this patient's OCT?

answers.explanation:
Central serous chorioretinopathy (CSCR) is a common idiopathic disorder that involves localized serous detachment of the neurosensory retina. CSCR falls within the pachychoroid disease spectrum, which is a constellation of diseases characterized by engorged Haller’s layer vessels in the choroid with choriocapillaris attenuation. In CSCR, this leads to subretinal fluid accumulation. The classic presentation involves decrease in vision in one eye of a young or middle-aged male. Risk factors for CSCR include hypertension, use of corticosteroids, male gender, Helicobacter pylori infection, type A personality and psychological stress.

​

References:

1. Haimovici R, Koh S, Gagnon DR, Lehrfeld T, Wellik S, Central Serous Chorioretinopathy Case–Control Study Group. Risk factors for central serous chorioretinopathy: a case–control study. Ophthalmology. 2004 Feb 1;111(2):244-9.
2. Lin J, Chen RW. Central serous chorioretinopathy. InManual of retinal diseases 2016 (pp. 421-426). Springer, Cham.

questions.title: Question 3
questions.text:
The patient's CSCR spontaneously resolved one month after observation with VA improving to 20/20. The patient was stable with VA of 20/20 at five-month follow-up. One year after his CSCR diagnosis, the patient presented with metamorphopsia and reduced VA of 20/20-2 in the right eye. An OCT of the right eye was conducted and is shown below:

![](/content/media/retina_72_3.webp)

What are the abnormalities seen on this OCT?

answers.explanation:
The OCT demonstrates subretinal hyperreflective material (red arrow). Subretinal Fluid can be seen nasally (yellow arrow). Enlarged choroidal vessels (blue stars) appear to have obliterated the choriocapillaris and Sattler’s layer.

![](/content/media/retina_72_4.webp)

The OCT demonstrated choroidal neovascular membranes as shown by the subretinal hyperreflective material, subretinal fluid and enlarged choroidal vessels. This entity is termed pachychoroid neovasculopathy.​

Pachychoroid spectrum is a term describing a group of clinical ophthalmologic diseases that share a common characteristic of choroidal thickening with pachyvessels. This spectrum of diseases includes pachychoroid neovasculopathy (PNV), pachychoroid pigment epitheliopathy, central serous chorioretinopathy, focal choroidal excavation and polypoidal choroidal vasculopathy.

References:

1. Sartini F, Figus M, Casini G, Nardi M, Posarelli C. Pachychoroid neovasculopathy: a type-1 choroidal neovascularization belonging to the pachychoroid spectrum—pathogenesis, imaging and available treatment options. International Ophthalmology. 2020 Dec;40(12):3577-89. 

2.Keidel LF, Schworm B, Priglinger SG, Siedlecki J. Pachychoroid Neovasculopathy Disguising as Age-Related Macular Degeneration Treated by Spironolactone and Anti-VEGF Combination Therapy. Case Reports in Ophthalmology. 2021;12(1):116-23. 

3.Tagawa M, Ooto S, Yamashiro K, Tamura H, Oishi A, Miyata M, Hata M, Yoshikawa M, Yoshimura N, Tsujikawa A. Characteristics of pachychoroid neovasculopathy. Scientific Reports. 2020 Oct 1;10(1):1-1.

questions.title: Question 5
questions.text:
The patient was immediately started on intravitreal anti-vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF) injection treatment with resolution of the subretinal fluid and hemorrhage. He was followed regularly with serial imaging for three years. OCT images of the right eye after three years since starting anti-VEGF therapy is shown below: A: at 16 months; B: at 21 months; C: at 29 months; D: at 37 months

![](/content/media/retina_72_5.webp)

What is the diagnosis?

answers.explanation:
This is a conforming focal choroidal excavation(FCE). It is acquired secondary to pachychoroid choroidal neovascular membrane following central serous chorioretinopathy.

Focal choroidal excavation (FCE) is a concavity in the choroid detected by optical coherence tomography (OCT) that was originally described by Jampol et al. in 2006 and named by Margolis et al. in 2011. Despite FCE classically being considered to be congenital there have been reports of acquired FCE following choroidal neovascular membrane CNVM and multiple evanescent white dot syndrome (MEWDS). This has led to the pathogenesis and prognosis of FCE being unclear, with a recent review by Verma et al. proposing an etiology- based classification where FCE is characterized as congenital/primary (i.e., no associated evidence of any other chorioretinal disease; generally stable and do not threaten vision) or acquired/secondary (i.e., acquired after birth; may progress and threaten vision).

​FCE can be acquired after pachychoroid spectrum disorders such as CSR and pCNVM. The mechanism of acquired FCE from CSR and pCNVM may be related to focal choroidal ischemia, collapse of choroid vessels, and fibrosis. Furthermore, FCE appears to be associated with the pachychoroid spectrum of diseases.

![](/content/media/retina_72_6.webp)

References:

1. Jampol LM, Shankle J, Schroeder R et al. Diagnostic and therapeutic challenges. Retina 2006; 26(9):1072–1076.
2. Margolis R, Mukkamala SK, Jampol LM et al. The expanded spectrum of focal choroidal excavation. Archives of ophthalmology 2011; 129(10):1320–1325.
3. Lee CS, Woo SJ, Kim YK, et al. Clinical and spectral-domain optical coherence tomography findings in patients with focal choroidal excavation. Ophthalmology 2014; 121(5):1029–1035.
4. Shah RC, Gopalakrishnan M, Goyal A et al. Focal choroidal excavation: Cause or effect?. Indian journal of ophthalmology 2019; 67(5):696–698.
5. Hashimoto Y, Saito W, Noda K, Ishida S. Acquired focal choroidal excavation associated with multiple evanescent white dot syndrome: observations at onset and a pathogenic hypothesis. BMC ophthalmology 2014; 14:13.
6. Verma S, Kumar V, Azad S et al. Focal choroidal excavation: review of literature. The British journal of ophthalmology 2021; 105(8):1043–1048.
